maml:description.maml:para: Adds members to a local group.
The `Add-LocalGroupMember` cmdlet adds users or groups to a local security group. All the rights and permissions that are assigned to a group are assigned to all members of that group.
Members of the Administrators group on a local computer have Full Control permissions on that computer. Limit the number of users in the Administrators group.
If the computer is joined to a domain, you can add user accounts, computer accounts, and group accounts from that domain and from trusted domains to a local group.
> [!NOTE] > If the computer is joined to a domain and you try to add a local user that has the same name as a > member of the domain it adds the domain member.
Specifies the security group to which this cmdlet adds members.
Specifies an array of users or groups that this cmdlet adds to a security group. You can specify users or groups by name, security ID (SID), or LocalPrincipal objects.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the name of the security group to which this cmdlet adds members.
Specifies an array of users or groups that this cmdlet adds to a security group. You can specify users or groups by name, security ID (SID), or LocalPrincipal objects.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the security ID of the security group to which this cmdlet adds members.
Specifies an array of users or groups that this cmdlet adds to a security group. You can specify users or groups by name, security ID (SID), or LocalPrincipal objects.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the security group to which this cmdlet adds members.
Specifies an array of users or groups that this cmdlet adds to a security group. You can specify users or groups by name, security ID (SID), or LocalPrincipal objects.
Specifies the name of the security group to which this cmdlet adds members.
Specifies the security ID of the security group to which this cmdlet adds members.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
You can pipe a local principal, a string, or a SID to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet does not generate any output.

maml:alert.maml:para: The Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts module is not available in 32-bit PowerShell on a 64-bit system.
The PrincipalSource property is a property on LocalUser , LocalGroup , and LocalPrincipal objects that describes the source of the object. The possible sources are as follows:
- Microsoft Account PrincipalSource is supported only by Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions of the Windows operating system. For earlier versions, the property is blank.

maml:description.maml:para: Disables a local user account.
The `Disable-LocalUser` cmdlet disables local user accounts. When a user account is disabled, the user cannot log on. When a user account is enabled, the user can log on.
> [!NOTE] > The Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts module is not available in 32-bit PowerShell on a > 64-bit system.
Specifies an array of user accounts that this cmdlet disables. To obtain a user account, use the `Get-LocalUser` cmdlet.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies an array of names of the user accounts that this cmdlet disables.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies an array of user accounts that this cmdlet disables.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies an array of user accounts that this cmdlet disables. To obtain a user account, use the `Get-LocalUser` cmdlet.
Specifies an array of names of the user accounts that this cmdlet disables.
Specifies an array of user accounts that this cmdlet disables.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
You can pipe a local user, a string, or a SID to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet does not generate any output.

maml:alert.maml:para: The PrincipalSource property is a property on LocalUser , LocalGroup *, and LocalPrincipal objects that describes the source of the object. The possible sources are as follows:
- Microsoft Account PrincipalSource is supported only by Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions of the Windows operating system. For earlier versions, the property is blank.

command:example.maml:title: ------ Example 1: Disable an account by specifying a name ------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command disables the user account named Admin02.

command:example.maml:title: ----- Example 2: Disable an account by using the pipeline -----

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the built-in Guest account by using `Get-LocalUser`, and then passes it to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator(`|`). That cmdlet disables that account.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables a local user account.
The `Enable-LocalUser` cmdlet enables local user accounts. When a user account is disabled, the user cannot log on. When a user account is enabled, the user can log on.
> [!NOTE] > The Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts module is not available in 32-bit PowerShell on a 64-bit > system.
Specifies an array of user accounts that this cmdlet enables. To obtain a user account, use the `Get-LocalUser` cmdlet.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies an array of names of the user accounts that this cmdlet enables.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies an array of user accounts that this cmdlet enables.

Specifies an array of user accounts that this cmdlet enables. To obtain a user account, use the `Get-LocalUser` cmdlet.

This cmdlet does not generate any output.

- Microsoft Account PrincipalSource is supported only by Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions of the Windows operating system. For earlier versions, the property is blank.

command:example.maml:title: ------ Example 1: Enable an account by specifying a name ------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command enables the user account named Admin02.

command:example.maml:title: ------ Example 2: Enable an account by using the pipeline ------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the built-in Administrator account by using `Get-LocalUser`, and then passes it to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. That cmdlet enables that account.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the local security groups.
The `Get-LocalGroup` cmdlet gets local security groups in Security Account Manager. This cmdlet gets default built-in groups and local security groups that you create.
> [!NOTE] > The Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts module is not available in 32-bit PowerShell on a 64-bit > system.
Specifies an array of names of security groups that this cmdlet gets. You can use the wildcard character.
Specifies an array of security IDs (SIDs) of security groups that this cmdlet gets.
Specifies an array of names of security groups that this cmdlet gets. You can use the wildcard character.
Specifies an array of security IDs (SIDs) of security groups that this cmdlet gets.
You can pipe a string or a SID to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns a local group.

maml:alert.maml:para: - The PrincipalSource property is a property on LocalUser , LocalGroup , and LocalPrincipal objects that describes the source of the object. The possible sources are as follows:
- Microsoft Account PrincipalSource is supported only by Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions of the Windows operating system. For earlier versions, the property is blank.

command:example.maml:title: ----------- Example 1: Get the Administrators group -----------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the local Administrators group. The command displays properties of the group in the console.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets members from a local group.
The `Get-LocalGroupMember` cmdlet gets members from a local group.
> [!NOTE] > The Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts module is not available in 32-bit PowerShell on a 64-bit > system.
Specifies the security group from which this cmdlet gets members.

Specifies a user or group that this cmdlet gets from a security group. You can specify users or groups by name or security ID (SID). Specify SID strings in S-R-I-S-S . . . format. You can use wildcard characters. If you do not specify this parameter, the cmdlet gets all members of the group.
Specifies the name of the security group from which this cmdlet gets members.

Specifies a user or group that this cmdlet gets from a security group. You can specify users or groups by name or security ID (SID). Specify SID strings in S-R-I-S-S . . . format. You can use wildcard characters. If you do not specify this parameter, the cmdlet gets all members of the group.
Specifies the security ID of the security group from which this cmdlet gets members.

Specifies a user or group that this cmdlet gets from a security group. You can specify users or groups by name or security ID (SID). Specify SID strings in S-R-I-S-S . . . format. You can use wildcard characters. If you do not specify this parameter, the cmdlet gets all members of the group.
Specifies the security group from which this cmdlet gets members.

Specifies a user or group that this cmdlet gets from a security group. You can specify users or groups by name or security ID (SID). Specify SID strings in S-R-I-S-S . . . format. You can use wildcard characters. If you do not specify this parameter, the cmdlet gets all members of the group.
Specifies the name of the security group from which this cmdlet gets members.
Specifies the security ID of the security group from which this cmdlet gets members.
You can pipe a local group, a string, or a SID to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns local principals.

maml:alert.maml:para: - The PrincipalSource property is a property on LocalUser , LocalGroup , and LocalPrincipal objects that describes the source of the object. The possible sources are as follows:
- Microsoft Account PrincipalSource is supported only by Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions of the Windows operating system. For earlier versions, the property is blank.

command:example.maml:title: ---- Example 1: Get all members of the Administrators group ----

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all the members of the local Administrators group.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets local user accounts.

The `Get-LocalUser` cmdlet gets local user accounts. This cmdlet gets default built-in user accounts, local user accounts that you created, and local accounts that you connected to Microsoft accounts.
> [!NOTE] > The Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts module is not available in 32-bit PowerShell on a 64-bit > system.
Specifies an array of names of user accounts that this cmdlet gets. You can use the wildcard character.
Specifies an array of security IDs (SIDs) of user accounts that this cmdlet gets.
Specifies an array of names of user accounts that this cmdlet gets. You can use the wildcard character.
Specifies an array of security IDs (SIDs) of user accounts that this cmdlet gets.
You can pipe a string or SID to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns local user accounts.

maml:alert.maml:para: The PrincipalSource property on LocalUser , LocalGroup , and LocalPrincipal objects describes the source of the object. The possible sources are as follows:
- Microsoft Account PrincipalSource is supported only by Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions of the Windows operating system. For earlier versions, the property is blank.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 1: Get an account by using its name ---------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-LocalUser -Name "AdminContoso02"
Name Enabled Description ---- ------- ----------- AdminContoso02 True Description of this account.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get an account that is connected to a Microsoft account
command:example.dev:code:
Get-LocalUser -Name "MicrosoftAccount\username@Outlook.com"
Name Enabled Description ---- ------- ----------- MicrosoftAccount\username@outlook.com True Description of this account.

command:example.maml:title: ----- Example 3: Get an account that has the specified SID -----
command:example.dev:code:
Get-LocalUser -SID S-1-5-21-9526073513-1762370368-3942940353-500
Name Enabled Description ---- ------- ----------- Administrator True Built-in account for administering the computer/domain

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a local security group.
The `New-LocalGroup` cmdlet creates a local security group in the Security Account Manager.
> [!NOTE] > The Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts module is not available in 32-bit PowerShell on a 64-bit > system.
Specifies a name for the group. The maximum length is 256 characters.
Specifies a comment for the group. The maximum length is 48 characters.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies a comment for the group. The maximum length is 48 characters.
Specifies a name for the group. The maximum length is 256 characters.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
You can pipe a string to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns a security group.

maml:alert.maml:para: ` The PrincipalSource property is a property on LocalUser , LocalGroup , and LocalPrincipal objects that describes the source of the object. The possible sources are as follows:
- Microsoft Account PrincipalSource is supported only by Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions of the Windows operating system. For earlier versions, the property is blank.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1: Create a security group --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a group named SecurityGroup04.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a local user account.
The `New-LocalUser` cmdlet creates a local user account. This cmdlet creates a local user account or a local user account that is connected to a Microsoft account.
> [!NOTE] > The Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts module is not available in 32-bit PowerShell on a 64-bit > system.
Specifies the user name for the user account.
If you create a local user account for the local system, the user name can contain up to 20 uppercase characters or lowercase characters. A user name cannot contain the following characters:
A user name cannot consist only of periods `.` or spaces.
Specifies when the user account expires. To obtain a DateTime object, use the `Get-Date` cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the account does not expire.
Indicates that the account does not expire.
Specifies a comment for the user account. The maximum length is 48 characters.
Indicates that this cmdlet creates the user account as disabled.
Specifies the full name for the user account. The full name differs from the user name of the user account.
Indicates that the user account does not have a password.
Indicates that the user cannot change the password on the user account.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the user name for the user account.
If you create a local user account for the local system, the user name can contain up to 20 uppercase characters or lowercase characters. A user name cannot contain the following characters:
A user name cannot consist only of periods `.` or spaces.
Specifies when the user account expires. To obtain a DateTime object, use the `Get-Date` cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the account does not expire.
Indicates that the account does not expire.
Specifies a comment for the user account. The maximum length is 48 characters.
Indicates that this cmdlet creates the user account as disabled.
Specifies the full name for the user account. The full name differs from the user name of the user account.
Specifies a password for the user account. You can use `Read-Host -AsSecureString`, `Get-Credential`, or `ConvertTo-SecureString` to create a SecureString object for the password.
If you omit the Password and NoPassword parameters, `New-LocalUser` prompts you for the new user's password.
Indicates whether the password expires.
Indicates that the user cannot change the password on the user account.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies when the user account expires. To obtain a DateTime object, use the `Get-Date` cmdlet. If you do not specify this parameter, the account does not expire.
Indicates that the account does not expire.
Specifies a comment for the user account. The maximum length is 48 characters.
Indicates that this cmdlet creates the user account as disabled.
Specifies the full name for the user account. The full name differs from the user name of the user account.
Specifies the user name for the user account.
If you create a local user account for the local system, the user name can contain up to 20 uppercase characters or lowercase characters. A user name cannot contain the following characters:
A user name cannot consist only of periods `.` or spaces.
Indicates that the user account does not have a password.
Specifies a password for the user account. You can use `Read-Host -AsSecureString`, `Get-Credential`, or `ConvertTo-SecureString` to create a SecureString object for the password.
If you omit the Password and NoPassword parameters, `New-LocalUser` prompts you for the new user's password.
Indicates whether the password expires.
Indicates that the user cannot change the password on the user account.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
You can pipe a string, a DateTime object, a boolean value, or a secure string to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns a LocalUser object. This object provides information about the user account.

maml:alert.maml:para: - A user name cannot be identical to any other user name or group name on the computer. A user name cannot consist only of periods `.` or spaces. A user name can contain up to 20 uppercase characters or lowercase characters. A user name cannot contain the following characters:
- A password can contain up to 127 characters.
- The PrincipalSource property is a property on LocalUser , LocalGroup , and LocalPrincipal objects that describes the source of the object. The possible sources are as follows:
- Local - Active Directory - Azure Active Directory group - Microsoft Account
> [!NOTE] > PrincipalSource is supported only by Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions of the > Windows operating system. For earlier versions, the property is blank.

command:example.maml:title: --------------- Example 1: Create a user account ---------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-LocalUser -Name "User02" -Description "Description of this account." -NoPassword Name Enabled Description ---- ------- ----------- User02 True Description of this account.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a local user account and does not specify the AccountExpires or Password parameters. Therefore, the account doesn't expire or have a password by default.

command:example.maml:title: ----- Example 2: Create a user account that has a password -----
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Password = Read-Host -AsSecureString PS C:\> New-LocalUser "User03" -Password $Password -FullName "Third User" -Description "Description of this account." Name Enabled Description ---- ------- ----------- User03 True Description of this account.

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command prompts you for a password by using the `Read-Host` cmdlet. The command stores the password as a secure string in the `$Password` variable.
The second command creates a local user account by using the password stored in `$Password`. The command specifies a user name, full name, and description for the user account.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes local security groups.

The `Remove-LocalGroup` cmdlet deletes local security groups. This cmdlet deletes only a local group. It does not delete the user accounts, computer accounts, or group accounts that belong to that group. You cannot recover a deleted group.

If you delete a group and then create another group that has the same group name, you must set new permissions for the new group. The new group does not inherit the permissions that were assigned to the group.
> [!NOTE] > The Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts module is not available in 32-bit PowerShell on a 64-bit > system.
Specifies an array of security groups that this cmdlet deletes. To obtain groups, use the `Get-LocalGroup` cmdlet.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies an array of names of the security groups that this cmdlet deletes.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies an array of security IDs (SIDs) of security groups that this cmdlet deletes.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies an array of security groups that this cmdlet deletes. To obtain groups, use the `Get-LocalGroup` cmdlet.
Specifies an array of names of the security groups that this cmdlet deletes.
Specifies an array of security IDs (SIDs) of security groups that this cmdlet deletes.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
You can pipe a security group, a string, or a SID to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet does not generate any output.

- Microsoft Account PrincipalSource is supported only by Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions of the Windows operating system. For earlier versions, the property is blank.

maml:alert.maml:para: - The PrincipalSource property is a property on LocalUser , LocalGroup , and LocalPrincipal objects that describes the source of the object. The possible sources are as follows:
- Microsoft Account PrincipalSource is supported only by Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions of the Windows operating system. For earlier versions, the property is blank.

command:example.maml:title: --------------- Example 1: Rename a user account ---------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command renames the user account named Admin02.

maml:description.maml:para: Changes a local security group.
The `Set-LocalGroup` cmdlet changes a local security group.
Specifies the security group that this cmdlet changes. To obtain a security group, use the Get-LocalGroup cmdlet.
Specifies a comment for the group. The maximum length is 48 characters.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the name of the security group that this cmdlet changes.
Specifies a comment for the group. The maximum length is 48 characters.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the security ID (SID) of the security group that this cmdlet changes.
Specifies a comment for the group. The maximum length is 48 characters.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies a comment for the group. The maximum length is 48 characters.
Specifies the security group that this cmdlet changes. To obtain a security group, use the Get-LocalGroup cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the security group that this cmdlet changes.
Specifies the security ID (SID) of the security group that this cmdlet changes.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
You can pipe a security group, a string, or a SID to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet does not generate any output.

maml:alert.maml:para: - The PrincipalSource property is a property on LocalUser , LocalGroup , and LocalPrincipal objects that describes the source of the object. The possible sources are as follows:
- Microsoft Account PrincipalSource is supported only by Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions of the Windows operating system. For earlier versions, the property is blank.

command:example.maml:title: ------------ Example 1: Change a group description ------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes the description of a local group.
> [!NOTE] > The Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts module is not available in 32-bit PowerShell on a 64-bit > system.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies a local user account.
The `Set-LocalUser` cmdlet modifies a local user account. This cmdlet can reset the password of a local user account.
> [!NOTE] > The Microsoft.PowerShell.LocalAccounts module is not available in 32-bit PowerShell on a 64-bit > system.
Specifies the user account that this cmdlet changes. To obtain a user account, use the `Get-LocalUser` cmdlet.
Specifies when the user account expires. To obtain a DateTime object, use the `Get-Date` cmdlet.
If you do not want the account to expire, specify the AccountNeverExpires parameter.
Indicates that the account does not expire.
Specifies a comment for the user account. The maximum length is 48 characters.
Specifies the full name for the user account. The full name differs from the user name of the user account.
Specifies a password for the user account. If the user account is connected to a Microsoft account, do not set a password.
You can use `Read-Host -GetCredential`, `Get-Credential`, or `ConvertTo-SecureString` to create a SecureString object for the password.
If you omit the Password and NoPassword parameters, `Set-LocalUser` prompts you for the user's password.
Indicates whether the password expires.
Indicates that the user can change the password on the user account.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the name of the user account that this cmdlet changes.
Specifies when the user account expires. To obtain a DateTime object, use the `Get-Date` cmdlet.
If you do not want the account to expire, specify the AccountNeverExpires parameter.
Indicates that the account does not expire.
Specifies a comment for the user account. The maximum length is 48 characters.
Specifies the full name for the user account. The full name differs from the user name of the user account.
Specifies a password for the user account. If the user account is connected to a Microsoft account, do not set a password.
You can use `Read-Host -GetCredential`, `Get-Credential`, or `ConvertTo-SecureString` to create a SecureString object for the password.
If you omit the Password and NoPassword parameters, `Set-LocalUser` prompts you for the user's password.
Indicates whether the password expires.
Indicates that the user can change the password on the user account.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the security ID (SID) of the user account that this cmdlet changes.
Specifies when the user account expires. To obtain a DateTime object, use the `Get-Date` cmdlet.
If you do not want the account to expire, specify the AccountNeverExpires parameter.
Indicates that the account does not expire.

Specifies a password for the user account. If the user account is connected to a Microsoft account, do not set a password.
You can use `Read-Host -GetCredential`, `Get-Credential`, or `ConvertTo-SecureString` to create a SecureString object for the password.
If you omit the Password and NoPassword parameters, `Set-LocalUser` prompts you for the user's password.
Indicates whether the password expires.
Indicates that the user can change the password on the user account.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies when the user account expires. To obtain a DateTime object, use the `Get-Date` cmdlet.
If you do not want the account to expire, specify the AccountNeverExpires parameter.
Indicates that the account does not expire.

Specifies the full name for the user account. The full name differs from the user name of the user account.
Specifies the user account that this cmdlet changes. To obtain a user account, use the `Get-LocalUser` cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the user account that this cmdlet changes.
Specifies a password for the user account. If the user account is connected to a Microsoft account, do not set a password.
You can use `Read-Host -GetCredential`, `Get-Credential`, or `ConvertTo-SecureString` to create a SecureString object for the password.
If you omit the Password and NoPassword parameters, `Set-LocalUser` prompts you for the user's password.

maml:alert.maml:para: - The PrincipalSource property is a property on LocalUser , LocalGroup , and LocalPrincipal objects that describes the source of the object. The possible sources are as follows:

command:example.maml:title: ------ Example 1: Change a description of a user account ------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes the description of a user account named Admin07.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 2: Change the password on an account ---------

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command prompts you for a password by using the Read-Host cmdlet. The command stores the password as a secure string in the $Password variable.
The second command gets a user account named User02 by using `Get-LocalUser`. The command stores the account in the $UserAccount variable.
The third command sets the new password on the user account stored in `$UserAccount`.
